parts: code for thermometer using Javascript canvas
flattened: code for thermometer using Javascript canvas

parts:
Here's an example code for a simple thermometer using Javascript and HTML5 Canvas:

HTML:
```html
<canvas id="thermometer" width="200" height="400"></canvas>
```

Javascript:
```javascript
const canvas = document.getElementById('thermometer');
const ctx = canvas.getContext('2d');

// Draw the thermometer background
ctx.fillStyle = '#fff'; // Set background color to white
ctx.fillRect(0, 0, canvas.width, canvas.height); // Fill the whole canvas with white
ctx.fillStyle = '#f00'; // Set fill color to red
ctx.fillRect(70, 50, 60, 300); // Draw the red part of the thermometer

// Draw the mercury
function drawMercury(percentage) {
  const mercuryHeight = 3 * canvas.height * percentage / 100 - 50; // Calculate the height of the mercury
  ctx.fillStyle = '#f90'; // Set fill color to orange
  ctx.fillRect(70, 50 + 300 - mercuryHeight, 60, mercuryHeight); // Draw the mercury
}

drawMercury(50); // Draw the mercury at 50% height
```

This code draws a thermometer with a red background and an orange mercury that fills the thermometer up to a given percentage (in this example, 50%). The `drawMercury()` function takes a percentage as an argument and calculates the height of the mercury accordingly. You can call this function with a different percentage to update the thermometer.

Here's an example code for a simple thermometer using Javascript and HTML5 Canvas:

HTML:
```html
<canvas id="thermometer" width="200" height="400"></canvas>
```

Javascript:
```javascript
const canvas = document.getElementById('thermometer');
const ctx = canvas.getContext('2d');

// Draw the thermometer background
ctx.fillStyle = '#fff'; // Set background color to white
ctx.fillRect(0, 0, canvas.width, canvas.height); // Fill the whole canvas with white
ctx.fillStyle = '#f00'; // Set fill color to red
ctx.fillRect(70, 50, 60, 300); // Draw the red part of the thermometer

// Draw the mercury
function drawMercury(percentage) {
  const mercuryHeight = 3 * canvas.height * percentage / 100 - 50; // Calculate the height of the mercury
  ctx.fillStyle = '#f90'; // Set fill color to orange
  ctx.fillRect(70, 50 + 300 - mercuryHeight, 60, mercuryHeight); // Draw the mercury
}

drawMercury(50); // Draw the mercury at 50% height
```

This code draws a thermometer with a red background and an orange mercury that fills the thermometer up to a given percentage (in this example, 50%). The `drawMercury()` function takes a percentage as an argument and calculates the height of the mercury accordingly. You can call this function with a different percentage to update the thermometer.
